Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

correspAction.roleName: U.S. Minister Resident and Consul General

div1.p:
Consulate General of the United States,
Monrovia, Liberia, Nov. 27, 1880.
Mr. J. H. Smyth to the Act'g Sec'y of State.

Consulate General of the United States,
Monrovia, Liberia, Nov. 27, 1880.
I have the honor to very respectfully acknowledge the receipt of your No. 16, consular series, containing an enclosure, bond in the blank with statement in reference to said official bond.
I was not a little surprised on reading the dispatch, and on reference to page 269, Consular Regulations of 1874, section 842 that, I was required to give a bond.

On my appointment I made inquiry as to whether I should give a bond or
Hon. John Hay,
Acting Secretary,
Washington, D.C.
or not, and was informed that one would not be required, since I held the dual relation of Minister Resident and Consul General.
By reference as above noted, see, "before he (Consul Gen'l, &c., &c.) receives his commission or enters upon the duties of his office," the bond must be given.
This gave me the impression that the previous information, that a bond was not required, was correct, otherwise my bond would have long since been given.

I have in compliance with your despatch signed the bond, and send it by this mail to Hon. B. K. Bruce, Senator, with request that he sign as my surety, and have advised him that Mr. Cromwell also sign as surety.

I
I very much regret that the matter was not called to my attention while in the United States.

With renewed assurances of highest esteem, I am, Sir,
Your obedient servant,
Jno. H. Smyth, U.S. Minister Resident &c., &c. Consul General.
